Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2008 11:17AM bevnurse wrote: Here you go Robin:Conference 5/3/2008 2nd Annual Conference for Women Living with Advanced Breast Cancer: Enhancing Your Health and Quality of Life Join us for our May 3, 2008, conference focusing exclusively on the medical, emotional and practical needs of women living with advanced breast cancer Plenary Speakers: Andrew D. Seidman, MD; Steven Rosenzweig, MD Join us for the 2nd Annual Conference for Women Living with Advanced Breast Cancer: Enhancing Your Health and Quality of Life from 9:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. on Saturday, May 3, 2008, at the Philadelphia Marriott West in West Conshohocken, Pa. The full-day program will feature the information, support and practical resources you need to make informed decisions for your physical and emotional health. Our plenary speaker, Andrew D. Seidman, MD, will discuss medical and research news relevant to women affected by advanced breast cancer. After the plenary session, choose from workshop topics including treatments, clinical trials, living with uncertainty, using nutrition to maintain well-being, workplace and insurance concerns, communicating with loved ones, end-of-life concerns and more. After a plated lunch, closing speaker Steven Rosenzweig, MD, will explain how to use integrative and complementary approaches in managing symptoms and side effects. Speakers Dr. Seidman is attending physician for the Breast Cancer Medicine Service at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and professor of medicine at Weill Medical College of Cornell University. He completed a fellowship in medical oncology and hematology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and received an award from the American Society of Clinical Oncology for his research on the role of taxanes in breast cancer treatment. He has served as president of the American Society of Breast Disease and as a member of the Cancer and Leukemia Group B Breast Committee. Dr. Seidman has authored over 120 peer-reviewed publications, reviews and chapters and has served on the editorial boards of several leading journals. His research focuses on the management of advanced breast cancer. Dr. Rosenzweig is an associate professor at Drexel University College of Medicine and adjunct associate professor at Jefferson Medical College. He served as past founding medical and academic director of the Jefferson Myrna Brind Center of Integrative Medicine. Dr. Rosenzweig's private practice focuses on people living with cancer and other chronic illnesses. He cares for people in all stages of treatment using integrative medicine to support, amplify and expand the benefits of conventional treatment alone. Dr. Rosenzweig emphasizes mind-body practices, bringing guided imagery and mindfulness-meditation instruction to those he serves. We are pleased to host the following workshop speakers: * Cyndi Dinger, RD, LDN, Nutrition Manager, MANNA (Metropolitan Area Neighborhood Nutrition Alliance) * Trudy D. Helge, PsyD, Director of Program Development and Health Psychology, Women's Mental Health Associates * Hester Hill Schnipper, LICSW, BCD, OSW-C, Chief of Oncology Social Work, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center * Carolyn Messner, DSW, MSW, LCSW-R, ACSW, BCD, Director of Education and Training, CancerCare * Carole F. Seddon, LCSW-C, BCD, OSW-C, Director of the Cancer Counseling Center, Duffey Family Patient and Family Services Program at Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center at Johns Hopkins General Information The conference will be held at the Philadelphia Marriott West at 111 Crawford Avenue in West Conshohocken, Pennsylvania 19428. You may contact the hotel at 610.941.5600 or 800.237.3639. A small room block with a reduced room rate has been reserved for conference participants. Please mention the Living Beyond Breast Cancer conference when making your reservations. Conshohocken is centrally located off I-476 near both I-95 and I-76. On-site parking is available for a $3 fee. SEPTA regional rail train R6 drops passengers off one-half mile from the hotel. For directions from area locations and airports, call the hotel or use the mapping tool at "http://www.marriott.com/hotels/travel/phlwe-philadelphia-marriott-west/". Registration and Travel Scholarships Registration is $35 per person and includes continental breakfast, lunch and networking. We are offering a limited number of travel scholarships and fee waivers for people in the United States and Canada. Registration and scholarship applications will be available soon. Sponsors The conference is supported by lead sponsor National Philanthropic Trust; presenting sponsor Bristol-Myers Squibb; title sponsors Abraxis BioScience, Inc. and AstraZeneca; and benefactors Genentech and The Wellness Community. Exhibitors and Partners Thank you to our conference exhibitors and partners for their support. We encourage you to visit with them onsite and check out their websites at the following links: * Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania * Abraxis BioScience, Inc. and AstraZeneca * Borders Express * CancerCare * Hayko Designs * Joan Karnell Cancer Center at Pennsylvania Hospital * The Legal Clinic for the Disabled, Inc * MANNA (Metropolitan Area Neighborhood Nutrition Alliance) * Metastatic Breast Cancer Network * Myrna Brind Center for Integrative Medicine, Thomas Jefferson University Hospital * The Wellness Community If you'd like information on becoming a conference exhibitor, email amy@lbbc.org! Tell Us What You Think If you wanted to attend last year's conference but did not, we want to hear from you. What would make it easier for you to attend-a different date, location, fee or conference length? Please send your feedback to Amy at amy@lbbc.org or call her at our office at 610.645.4567.
Posts.Title: know anything more about the lbbc. org conference freeariesonline waterlily

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2008 07:34PM bevnurse wrote: Ah fitz, I hope you are feeling better. I can really identify with your weekend...actually more with how you felt. It's interesting that so many of us have had a recent particularly sucky time lately. Makes me wonder if the is some cyclical rhythm to it. I just feel so out of sorts, angry, sad, defeated, etc. but am perpetually working at keeping up the false facade to keep dh and kids comfy. I finally lost it with my dh this weekend because he still just doesn't get it (as someone else mentioned it was 2x4 (US equivelent) time) and continues to insist this will be the chemo that works and I will get  through it and life will continue as before...aarrrrgggh! Dear GOD it's like living in a make believe world and it is exhausting. I think Shirlann had a brilliant suggestion: Anti-depressants. I just cannot feel like this anymore and that is about the only thing I haven't tried yet! Well, as I said earlier, I hope you are in a better place today. I just keep trying to think that this is a phase of the process and something more terrible is waiting around the corner so I best enjoy the moment ! Hugs to you, Bev
Posts.Title: Depression, Anxiety and Mets oh my! Fitztwins Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2007 07:38PM bevnurse wrote: Hang in there Wendy!  You didn't say how old your son is but don't beat yourself up to bad. When my son was 2 he fell and broke his collar bone...I missed it for 10 hours and I have been an ED nurse for years! I thought he was just complaining to keep from having to go to bed. So yes, I know that "mother of the year" feeling. Sometimes an appy can hide pretty well until it hits that rupture point.  You are just a Mom not a mind reader!! I have seen ED doc's send people home only to have them return the next day with an active appy..it happens even with all of the tests.  The important thing is that he is improving. Get a good nights sleep so you can slobber all over him when he comes home...that's the medicine he will need and respond to. Remember to take care of yourself both physically and emotionally so that you can take care of the rest of the family...husbands are great but they aren't Mom! Hugs to you, Bev
Posts.Title: What a horrible week WendyV LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2008 08:31PM bevnurse wrote: AWESOME, AWESOME!!! That's what we need to see some positive movement. You go gurl!!! Hugs, Bev
Posts.Title: OK...the docs have a plan. AlaskaDeb LuAnnH

Posts.Content: bevnurse wrote: Live in complete infuriating denial!!!! Well, I got the official word on Monday that my cancer is back in the same chest wall area (much larger area) only this time the onc passed it off as fat necrosis from my DIEP recon for 6 weeks. Fortunately 2 weeks later my PS went in to do a biopsy so we could see exactly what it was. So I start again...staging exams and treatment. This go round however is being described as long term (she won't say I'm Stage IV) with herceptin and abraxane. I had my MUGA and then first chemo infusion Wednesday. Post placement today and staging exams next week...dear GOD I forgot how this all takes over!! And now the wait for scan results, arrgghh. Of course the family line is "it's only a set back"(that has got to be the world's biggest understatement, not getting the job you wanted is a set back this is life and death folks), "you beat it before you can do it again"(really? If I beat it before why am I having to go through all this shit again??), "you are so strong you will get through this just fine" (no really I am that pile of jelly in the corner trying to remember what my name is). Oh yes, and my DH has once again shaved his head so that I can walk around with the billboard that says "My wife has breast cancer and i'm being supportive". It was sweet the first time now it's just irritating the hell out of me (of course in all fairness everything is irritating me right now!) It is so nice to come here and vent. Beverly Dx 11/11/2004, IDC, 4cm, Stage II, Grade 3, 1/8 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: losing my head while all those around me... bevnurse Catherine45

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2008 02:01AM bevnurse wrote: Thanks so much everyone. It really is amazing to me how much it helps to put all of the things you want to say but would be locked up if you did on a message board. It is so nice that you all "know" exactly what I mean and how I feel.  LuAnn, I have been thinking about why my onc wouldn't commit to saying I was Stage IV vs local recurrence. All I can come up with is the lack of scan results. She is probably "assuming" something is going on elsewhere which would make me stage IV but she can't say that because I haven't been scanned yet. During my last local recurrence (4/2006) the surgeon made the mistake of verbalizing her belief that there was already spread prior to scans and fortunately had to eat her words! And yes I agree with you wish, this continued increase in members just SUCKS!
Posts.Title: losing my head while all those around me... bevnurse Catherine45

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2008 09:23PM - edited Jul 28, 2008 09:24PM by bevnurse Hi Jon, No problem with the waiting part today. The good news:The Radiologist took pity on me 'cause he tried to call the results to my onc who is on vacation until next week. The bad news: Mets to the sternum, skull and tip of the left hip :(... I could just vomit
Posts.Title: losing my head while all those around me... bevnurse Catherine45

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 11:23PM bevnurse wrote: Janis, Responded back, thanks. Did the Bone scan by myself...that won't happen again!!! Yeah I cried on the scan table too! Plus they used my 1 week old port for the first time (SOB) and that was with lidocaine cream on it for an hour...that gets better right? Go ahead and lie to me if you must but good god tell me it gets better?!? So the tech responds to my tears telling me it will be ok...WHAT??? It will never be OK again for the rest of my now potentially shortened life you moron (of course I could be a little irritable right now so I uncharachteristically held my tongue)!!! I know he was trying to be helpful but that was absolutely the right time to shut the hell up and let me toddle off on my way. Men! OK, time to take my xanax and sink into the black abyss (sleep). Sleep well ladies and if you can't know that I pray for you all, Bev
Posts.Title: losing my head while all those around me... bevnurse Catherine45

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 06:17PM - edited Aug 2, 2008 06:32PM by bevnurse Thanks so much for all of the positive vibes ladies! In my head I know this is not a death sentence but logic is having a really hard time being heard over the screaming meemees right now. OMG Mrs x, I had to laught at the eyebrow and eye lash comment but I am afraid my DH would really do it...one lizard looking person in the house is more than enough!! Thanks for the offer Jon but I decided to go with xanax instead...great stuff for hiding from reality and a lot less mess :). And yes, the plan was to add zometa if there were bone mets. OK, so I climbed down out of the crazy tree (thanks kimmytwo, perfect description) long enough to face the body scan yesterday! So major scanxiety, made my DH come and hold my hand while I waited to go in for the scan. I was trying to explain why the waiting is so hard so here are my analogies: ...Like playing Russian roulette and holding a half cocked gun to your temple for 3-7 days ...Like watching a really intense horror movie and you get to the scary part where you know the person should not (go upstairs, open the door, look outside...you get the idea) and you have to wait for 3-7 days to see what is behind the door Feel free to add your descriptions. But again thanks so much and big hugs to you all

Posts.Content: bevnurse wrote: Ok, so "they" told me my hair would thin because of the abraxane but it seems "they" have under reported the thinning part. I have had 3 treatments and my hair has thinned by about 50%. Every morning I wash my hair and there appears to be a small rodent on the floor of the shower, everytime I touch my hair more falls out and I "shed" all day long! So right now I have "old lady" cotton candy hair and am facing at least 4 more months of abraxane. My question is does the thining stop or does it keep falling out with every treatment? Should I start looking for a new wig? Thanks everyone, Bev Beverly Dx 11/11/2004, IDC, 4cm, Stage II, Grade 3, 1/8 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Abraxane and hair loss bevnurse Kasey

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2008 11:39PM bevnurse wrote: It has been pretty easy so far. It hits the RBC, hemoglobin and hematocrit counts pretty hard so I am totally wiped out a day after the third treatment but it only lasts a couple days. It makes the taste of food different so I have had less of an appetite (not really a bad thing) but that bounces back on the off week. It is much easier to do than taxotere! I hope it is easy for you as it has been for me.  Hugs, Bev
Posts.Title: Abraxane and hair loss bevnurse Kasey

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2007 01:18AM bevnurse wrote: Hi LuAnn,  My prayers are with you, your DIL, and your son. My son was in Iraq for 15 months and returned in February. He is now home and done with his active duty requirements for the Army.  They do have access to the internet at most bases over there now and they usually get a 2 week leave about midway through the deployment. According to my son they asked everyone if there was a special occassion they wanted to be home for and tried to schedule them first. We got regular emails and phone calls...one or the other atleast every 2 weeks or so. He was able to check his my space account more often so I would sign on to see if he was checking in that way.  The other godsend was www.proudarmymom.com. These ladies saved my sanity. Tons of information and lots of support. Hugs, Bev
Posts.Title: O/T My son is leaving for Iraq LuAnnH mrs_X_Sunneedazee

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2007 02:41AM bevnurse wrote: As bad as the "cancer bitch" title was I was more offended when Lynette's husband said he was tired of making love to a sick person !!! Are you kidding me? Do men really think that way? Is that all we become in the marriage, the sick person? Is fighting cancer a practice in self absorbtion? At times, absolutely. It's just like training for a fight or an athletic competition. It takes concentration and intensity to get through the surgery, chemo, radiation, waiting for scan tests and results. Without that focus we would lose our minds. Was it a great depiction of a cancer patient...no but hey it's not really a great depiction of womanhood, motherhood or friendship why do we expect something different? It's Hollywood folks, reality is a bothersome detail! That's entertainment. Hugs, Bev
